  • option.static-routes-only - Indicates whether the connection has static routes only. Used for devices that do not support Border Gateway Protocol (BGP).

  • route.destination-cidr-block - The destination CIDR block. This corresponds to the subnet used in a customer data center.

  • bgp-asn - The BGP Autonomous System Number (ASN) associated with a BGP device.

  • tag:key=value - The key/value combination of a tag assigned to the resource.

  • tag-key - The key of a tag assigned to the resource. This filter is independent of the tag-value filter. For example, if you use both the filter "tag-key=Purpose" and the filter "tag-value=X", you get any resources assigned both the tag key Purpose (regardless of what the tag's value is), and the tag value X (regardless of what the tag's key is). If you want to list only resources where Purpose is X, see the tag:key=value filter.

  • tag-value - The value of a tag assigned to the resource. This filter is independent of the tag-key filter.

  • type - The type of VPN connection. Currently the only supported type is ipsec.1.

  • vpn-connection-id - The ID of the VPN connection.

  • vpn-gateway-id - The ID of a virtual private gateway associated with the VPN connection.

VpnConnectionIds.documentation:
One or more VPN connection IDs.

Default: Describes your VPN connections.

VpnConnections.documentation: Information about one or more VPN connections.

Filters.documentation:
One or more filters.

  • attachment.state - The current state of the attachment between the gateway and the VPC (attaching | attached | detaching | detached).

  • attachment.vpc-id - The ID of an attached VPC.

  • availability-zone - The Availability Zone for the virtual private gateway.

  • state - The state of the virtual private gateway (pending | available | deleting | deleted).

  • tag:key=value - The key/value combination of a tag assigned to the resource.

  • tag-key - The key of a tag assigned to the resource. This filter is independent of the tag-value filter. For example, if you use both the filter "tag-key=Purpose" and the filter "tag-value=X", you get any resources assigned both the tag key Purpose (regardless of what the tag's value is), and the tag value X (regardless of what the tag's key is). If you want to list only resources where Purpose is X, see the tag:key=value filter.

  • tag-value - The value of a tag assigned to the resource. This filter is independent of the tag-key filter.

  • type - The type of virtual private gateway. Currently the only supported type is ipsec.1.

  • vpn-gateway-id - The ID of the virtual private gateway.

VpnGatewayIds.documentation:
One or more virtual private gateway IDs.

Default: Describes all your virtual private gateways.

VpnGateways.documentation: Information about one or more virtual private gateways.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the instance to unlink from the VPC.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC to which the instance is linked.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

Force.documentation: Forces detachment if the previous detachment attempt did not occur cleanly (for example, logging into an instance, unmounting the volume, and detaching normally). This option can lead to data loss or a corrupted file system. Use this option only as a last resort to detach a volume from a failed instance. The instance won't have an opportunity to flush file system caches or file system metadata. If you use this option, you must perform file system check and repair procedures.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

Values.documentation: One or more values for the DHCP option.

DhcpConfigurations.documentation: One or more DHCP options in the set.

DhcpOptionsId.documentation: The ID of the set of DHCP options.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the DHCP options set.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

AssociationId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The association ID. Required for EC2-VPC.

PublicIp.documentation: [EC2-Classic] The Elastic IP address. Required for EC2-Classic.

AssociationId.documentation: The association ID representing the current association between the route table and subnet.

Checksum.documentation: The checksum computed for the disk image.

ImportManifestUrl.documentation: A presigned URL for the import manifest stored in Amazon S3. For information about creating a presigned URL for an Amazon S3 object, read the "Query String Request Authentication Alternative" section of the Authenticating REST Requests topic in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide.

A presigned URL for the import manifest stored in Amazon S3 and presented here as an Amazon S3 presigned URL. For information about creating a presigned URL for an Amazon S3 object, read the "Query String Request Authentication Alternative" section of the Authenticating REST Requests topic in the Amazon Simple Storage Service Developer Guide.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the Amazon EBS volume is deleted on instance termination.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the Amazon EBS volume is encrypted. Encrypted Amazon EBS volumes may only be attached to instances that support Amazon EBS encryption.

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For General Purpose (SSD) volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information on General Purpose (SSD) baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

Constraint: Range is 100 to 20000 for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes and 3 to 10000 for General Purpose (SSD) volumes.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1 volumes; it is not used in requests to create standard or gp2 volumes.

VolumeSize.documentation:
The size of the volume, in GiB.

Constraints: 1-1024 for standard volumes, 1-16384 for gp2 volumes, and 4-16384 for io1 volumes. If you specify a snapshot, the volume size must be equal to or larger than the snapshot size.

Default: If you're creating the volume from a snapshot and don't specify a volume size, the default is the snapshot size.

VolumeType.documentation:
The volume type. gp2 for General Purpose (SSD) volumes, io1 for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes, and standard for Magnetic volumes.

Default: standard

EbsInstanceBlockDevice.documentation: Describes a parameter used to set up an Amazon EBS volume in a block device mapping.

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the volume is deleted on instance termination.

VolumeId.documentation: The ID of the Amazon EBS volume.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the volume is deleted on instance termination.

VolumeId.documentation: The ID of the Amazon EBS volume.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

Description.documentation: A description of the resource being exported.

State.documentation: The state of the conversion task.

StatusMessage.documentation: The status message related to the export task.

ContainerFormat.documentation: The container format used to combine disk images with metadata (such as OVF). If absent, only the disk image is exported.

S3Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket for the destination image. The destination bucket must exist and grant WRITE and READ_ACP permissions to the AWS account vm-import-export@amazon.com.

S3Prefix.documentation: The image is written to a single object in the Amazon S3 bucket at the S3 key s3prefix + exportTaskId + '.' + diskImageFormat.

Filter.documentation: A filter name and value pair that is used to return a more specific list of results. Filters can be used to match a set of resources by various criteria, such as tags, attributes, or IDs.

Name.documentation: The name of the filter. Filter names are case-sensitive.

Values.documentation: One or more filter values. Filter values are case-sensitive.

Timestamp.documentation: The time the output was last updated.
The time the data was last updated.

Arn.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile.

Code.documentation: The ICMP type. A value of -1 means all types.

Type.documentation: The ICMP code. A value of -1 means all codes for the specified ICMP type.

CreationDate.documentation: The date and time the image was created.

Description.documentation: The description of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

ImageOwnerAlias.documentation: The AWS account alias (for example, amazon, self) or the AWS account ID of the AMI owner.

KernelId.documentation: The kernel associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

Name.documentation: The name of the AMI that was provided during image creation.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the image owner.

Platform.documentation: The value is Windows for Windows AMIs; otherwise blank.

ProductCodes.documentation: Any product codes associated with the AMI.

Public.documentation: Indicates whether the image has public launch permissions. The value is true if this image has public launch permissions or false if it has only implicit and explicit launch permissions.

RamdiskId.documentation: The RAM disk associated with the image, if any. Only applicable for machine images.

RootDeviceName.documentation: The device name of the root device (for example, /dev/sda1 or /dev/xvda).

RootDeviceType.documentation: The type of root device used by the AMI. The AMI can use an Amazon EBS volume or an instance store volume.

State.documentation: The current state of the AMI. If the state is available, the image is successfully registered and can be used to launch an instance.

VirtualizationType.documentation: The type of virtualization of the AMI.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

ImageDiskContainer.documentation: The disk container object for an ImportImage task.

DeviceName.documentation: The Amazon EBS block device mapping for the disk (optional).

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image being imported (optional).

SnapshotId.documentation: The Amazon EBS snapshot ID to be used for importing the snapshot.

Url.documentation: The URL to the Amazon S3-based disk image being imported. The URL can either be a https URL (https://..) or an Amazon S3 URL (s3://..)

Architecture.documentation: The architecture of the virtual machine being imported (optional).

ClientToken.documentation: The token to enable idempotency for VM import requests (optional).

Description.documentation: A description string for the import image task (optional).

LicenseType.documentation:
The license type to be used for the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) after importing (optional).

Note: You may only use BYOL if you have existing licenses with rights to use these licenses in a third party cloud like AWS. For more information, see VM Import/Export Prerequisites in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

Valid Values: AWS | BYOL

Platform.documentation: The operating system of the virtual machine being imported (optional).

RoleName.documentation: The name of the role to use when not using the default role name 'vmimport' (optional).

Architecture.documentation: Architecture of the virtual machine being imported.

ImageId.documentation: The Amazon Machine Image (AMI) ID created by the import task.

ImportTaskId.documentation: The task id of the ImportImage task.

LicenseType.documentation: License type of the virtual machine being imported.

Platform.documentation: Operating system of the VM being imported.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message of the import task.

ImageId.documentation: The Amazon Machine Image (AMI) ID of the imported virtual machine.

LicenseType.documentation: License type of the VM being imported.

Platform.documentation: The description string for the import image task.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of progress of the ImportImage task.

Status.documentation: A brief status for the ImportImage task.

StatusMessage.documentation: A descriptive status message for the ImportImage task.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type. This is not supported for VMs imported into a VPC, which are assigned the default security group. After a VM is imported into a VPC, you can specify another security group using the AWS Management Console. For more information, see Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux. For more information about the Linux instance types you can import, see Before You Get Started in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: [EC2-VPC] Optionally, you can use this parameter to assign the instance a specific available IP address from the IP address range of the subnet.

SubnetId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the subnet to launch the instance into.

UserData.documentation: User data to be made available to the instance.

Description.documentation: A description for the instance being imported.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone where the resulting instance will reside.

BytesConverted.documentation: The number of bytes converted so far.

Status.documentation: The status of the import of this particular disk image.

StatusMessage.documentation: The status information or errors related to the disk image.

KeyName.documentation: A unique name for the key pair.

PublicKeyMaterial.documentation: The public key. You must base64 encode the public key material before sending it to AWS.

KeyFingerprint.documentation: The MD5 public key fingerprint as specified in section 4 of RFC 4716.

ClientToken.documentation: Token to enable idempotency for VM import requests (optional).

Description.documentation: The description string for the ImportSnapshot task.

RoleName.documentation: The name of the role to use when not using the default role name 'vmimport' (optional).

ImportTaskId.documentation: The task ID of the ImportSnapshot task.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the resulting Amazon EBS volume.

Description.documentation: An optional description for the volume being imported.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone where the resulting volume will reside.

BytesConverted.documentation: The number of bytes converted so far.

Description.documentation: The description you provided when starting the import volume task.

AmiLaunchIndex.documentation: The AMI launch index, which can be used to find this instance in the launch group.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: Any block device mapping entries for the instance.

ClientToken.documentation: The idempotency token you provided when you launched the instance.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

IamInstanceProfile.documentation: The IAM instance profile associated with the instance.

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the AMI used to launch the instance.

InstanceLifecycle.documentation: Indicates whether this is a Spot Instance.

KeyName.documentation: The name of the key pair, if this instance was launched with an associated key pair.

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: [EC2-VPC] One or more network interfaces for the instance.

Platform.documentation: The value is Windows for Windows instances; otherwise blank.

PrivateDnsName.documentation: The private DNS name assigned to the instance. This DNS name can only be used inside the Amazon EC2 network. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IP address assigned to the instance.

ProductCodes.documentation: The product codes attached to this instance.

PublicDnsName.documentation: The public DNS name assigned to the instance. This name is not available until the instance enters the running state.

PublicIpAddress.documentation: The public IP address assigned to the instance.

RamdiskId.documentation: The RAM disk associated with this instance.

RootDeviceType.documentation: The root device type used by the AMI. The AMI can use an Amazon EBS volume or an instance store volume.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups for the instance.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Specifies whether to enable an instance launched in a VPC to perform NAT. This controls whether source/destination checking is enabled on the instance. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. The value must be false for the instance to perform NAT. For more information, see NAT Instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot Instance request.

State.documentation: The current state of the instance.

StateReason.documentation: The reason for the most recent state transition.

StateTransitionReason.documentation: The reason for the most recent state transition. This might be an empty string.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which the instance is running.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC in which the instance is running.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: The block device mapping of the instance.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance through the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O.

Groups.documentation: The security groups associated with the instance.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

RootDeviceName.documentation: The name of the root device (for example, /dev/sda1 or /dev/xvda).

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT.

DeviceName.documentation: The device name exposed to the instance (for example, /dev/sdh or xvdh).

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to automatically set up Amazon EBS volumes when the instance is launched.

DeviceName.documentation: The device name exposed to the instance (for example, /dev/sdh or xvdh).

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to automatically set up Amazon EBS volumes when the instance is launched.

NoDevice.documentation: suppress the specified device included in the block device mapping.

InstanceCount.documentation: he number of listed Reserved Instances in the state specified by the state.

State.documentation: The states of the listed Reserved Instances.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of the resource being exported.

InstanceMonitoring.documentation: Describes the monitoring information of the instance.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP associated with the network interface.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that created the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The IP address of the network interface within the subnet.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: The private IP addresses associated with the network interface.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether to validate network traffic to or from this network interface.

InstanceNetworkInterfaceAssociation.documentation: Describes association information for an Elastic IP address.

IpOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the owner of the Elastic IP address.

PublicIp.documentation: The public IP address or Elastic IP address bound to the network interface.

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

AttachmentId.documentation: The ID of the network interface attachment.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device on the instance for the network interface attachment.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Indicates whether to assign a public IP address to an instance you launch in a VPC. The public IP address can only be assigned to a network interface for eth0, and can only be assigned to a new network interface, not an existing one. You cannot specify more than one network interface in the request. If launching into a default subnet, the default value is true.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: If set to true, the interface is deleted when the instance is terminated. You can specify true only if creating a new network interface when launching an instance.

Description.documentation: The description of the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device on the instance for the network interface attachment. If you are specifying a network interface in a RunInstances request, you must provide the device index.

Groups.documentation: The IDs of the security groups for the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IP address of the network interface. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: One or more private IP addresses to assign to the network interface. Only one private IP address can be designated as primary.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IP addresses. You can't specify this option and specify more than one private IP address using the private IP addresses option.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet associated with the network string. Applies only if creating a network interface when launching an instance.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP address for the network interface.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether this IP address is the primary private IP address of the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The private IP address of the network interface.

InstanceState.documentation: Describes the current state of the instance.

Code.documentation:
The low byte represents the state. The high byte is an opaque internal value and should be ignored.

  • 0 : pending

  • 16 : running

  • 32 : shutting-down

  • 48 : terminated

  • 64 : stopping

  • 80 : stopped

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the instance.

Events.documentation: Extra information regarding events associated with the instance.

InstanceState.documentation: The intended state of the instance. DescribeInstanceStatus requires that an instance be in the running state.

InstanceStatus.documentation: Reports impaired functionality that stems from issues internal to the instance, such as impaired reachability.

SystemStatus.documentation: Reports impaired functionality that stems from issues related to the systems that support an instance, such as hardware failures and network connectivity problems.

ImpairedSince.documentation: The time when a status check failed. For an instance that was launched and impaired, this is the time when the instance was launched.

NotAfter.documentation: The latest scheduled end time for the event.

NotBefore.documentation: The earliest scheduled start time for the event.

Details.documentation: The system instance health or application instance health.

Attachments.documentation: Any VPCs attached to the Internet gateway.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the Internet gateway.

InternetGatewayAttachment.documentation: Describes the attachment of a VPC to an Internet gateway.

State.documentation: The current state of the attachment.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP types.

IpProtocol.documentation:
The protocol.

When you call DescribeSecurityGroups, the protocol value returned is the number. Exception: For TCP, UDP, and ICMP, the value returned is the name (for example, tcp, udp, or icmp). For a list of protocol numbers, see Protocol Numbers. (VPC only) When you call AuthorizeSecurityGroupIngress, you can use -1 to specify all.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code. A value of -1 indicates all ICMP codes for the specified ICMP type.

UserIdGroupPairs.documentation: One or more security group and AWS account ID pairs.

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR range. You can either specify a CIDR range or a source security group, not both.

KeyFingerprint.documentation: The SHA-1 digest of the DER encoded private key.

KeyMaterial.documentation: An unencrypted PEM encoded RSA private key.

KeyFingerprint.documentation: If you used CreateKeyPair to create the key pair, this is the SHA-1 digest of the DER encoded private key. If you used ImportKeyPair to provide AWS the public key, this is the MD5 public key fingerprint as specified in section 4 of RFC4716.

Add.documentation: The AWS account ID to add to the list of launch permissions for the AMI.

Remove.documentation: The AWS account ID to remove from the list of launch permissions for the AMI.

LaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for an instance.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. To request an instance in a nondefault VPC, you must specify the ID of the security group. To request an instance in EC2-Classic or a default VPC, you can specify the name or the ID of the security group.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instance.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data to make available to the instances.

Attribute.documentation: The name of the attribute to modify.

ProductCodes.documentation: One or more product codes. After you add a product code to an AMI, it can't be removed. This is only valid when modifying the productCodes attribute.

UserGroups.documentation: One or more user groups. This is only valid when modifying the launchPermission attribute.

UserIds.documentation: One or more AWS account IDs. This is only valid when modifying the launchPermission attribute.

Value.documentation: The value of the attribute being modified. This is only valid when modifying the description attribute.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
Modifies the DeleteOnTermination attribute for volumes that are currently attached. The volume must be owned by the caller. If no value is specified for DeleteOnTermination, the default is true and the volume is deleted when the instance is terminated.

To add instance store volumes to an Amazon EBS-backed instance, you must add them when you launch the instance. For more information, see Updating the Block Device Mapping when Launching an Instance in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If the value is true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Specifies whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Groups.documentation: [EC2-VPC] Changes the security groups of the instance. You must specify at least one security group, even if it's just the default security group for the VPC. You must specify the security group ID, not the security group name.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Specifies whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

InstanceType.documentation: Changes the instance type to the specified value. For more information, see Instance Types. If the instance type is not valid, the error returned is InvalidInstanceAttributeValue.

Kernel.documentation: Changes the instance's kernel to the specified value. We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB.

Ramdisk.documentation: Changes the instance's RAM disk to the specified value. We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Specifies whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means that checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT.

SriovNetSupport.documentation:
Set to simple to enable enhanced networking for the instance.

There is no way to disable enhanced networking at this time.

This option is supported only for HVM instances. Specifying this option with a PV instance can make it unreachable.

UserData.documentation: Changes the instance's user data to the specified value.

Value.documentation: A new value for the attribute. Use only with the kernel, ramdisk, userData, disableApiTermination, or intanceInitiateShutdownBehavior attribute.

Attachment.documentation: Information about the interface attachment. If modifying the 'delete on termination' attribute, you must specify the ID of the interface attachment.

Groups.documentation: Changes the security groups for the network interface. The new set of groups you specify replaces the current set. You must specify at least one group, even if it's just the default security group in the VPC. You must specify the ID of the security group, not the name.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether source/destination checking is enabled. A value of true means checking is enabled, and false means checking is disabled. This value must be false for a NAT instance to perform NAT. For more information, see NAT Instances in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive token you provide to ensure idempotency of your modification request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

ReservedInstancesIds.documentation: The IDs of the Reserved Instances to modify.

TargetConfigurations.documentation: The configuration settings for the Reserved Instances to modify.

CreateVolumePermission.documentation: A JSON representation of the snapshot attribute modification.

GroupNames.documentation: The group to modify for the snapshot.

OperationType.documentation: The type of operation to perform to the attribute.

UserIds.documentation: The account ID to modify for the snapshot.

MapPublicIpOnLaunch.documentation: Specify true to indicate that instances launched into the specified subnet should be assigned public IP address.

AutoEnableIO.documentation: Indicates whether the volume should be auto-enabled for I/O operations.

EnableDnsHostnames.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances launched in the VPC get DNS hostnames. If enabled, instances in the VPC get DNS hostnames; otherwise, they do not.

You can only enable DNS hostnames if you also enable DNS support.

EnableDnsSupport.documentation: Indicates whether the DNS resolution is supported for the VPC. If enabled, queries to the Amazon provided DNS server at the 169.254.169.253 IP address, or the reserved IP address at the base of the VPC network range "plus two" will succeed. If disabled, the Amazon provided DNS service in the VPC that resolves public DNS hostnames to IP addresses is not enabled.

InstanceMonitorings.documentation: Monitoring information for one or more instances.

State.documentation: Indicates whether monitoring is enabled for the instance.

Associations.documentation: Any associations between the network ACL and one or more subnets

Entries.documentation: One or more entries (rules) in the network ACL.

IsDefault.documentation: Indicates whether this is the default network ACL for the VPC.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the network ACL.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC for the network ACL.

NetworkAclAssociation.documentation: Describes an association between a network ACL and a subnet.

NetworkAclAssociationId.documentation: The ID of the association between a network ACL and a subnet.

NetworkAclEntry.documentation: Describes an entry in a network ACL.

CidrBlock.documentation: The network range to allow or deny, in CIDR notation.

Egress.documentation: Indicates whether the rule is an egress rule (applied to traffic leaving the subnet).

IcmpTypeCode.documentation: ICMP protocol: The ICMP type and code.

PortRange.documentation: TCP or UDP protocols: The range of ports the rule applies to.

Protocol.documentation: The protocol. A value of -1 means all protocols.

RuleAction.documentation: Indicates whether to allow or deny the traffic that matches the rule.

RuleNumber.documentation: The rule number for the entry. ACL entries are processed in ascending order by rule number.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP associated with the network interface.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

Groups.documentation: Any security groups for the network interface.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The IP address of the network interface within the subnet.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: The private IP addresses associated with the network interface.

RequesterId.documentation: The ID of the entity that launched the instance on your behalf (for example, AWS Management Console or Auto Scaling).

RequesterManaged.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is being managed by AWS.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: Indicates whether traffic to or from the instance is validated.

TagSet.documentation: Any tags assigned to the network interface.

NetworkInterfaceAssociation.documentation: Describes association information for an Elastic IP address.

IpOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the Elastic IP address owner.

PublicIp.documentation: The address of the Elastic IP address bound to the network interface.

AttachTime.documentation: The timestamp indicating when the attachment initiated.

AttachmentId.documentation: The ID of the network interface attachment.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The device index of the network interface attachment on the instance.

InstanceOwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the instance.

AttachmentId.documentation: The ID of the network interface attachment.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the network interface is deleted when the instance is terminated.

NetworkInterfacePrivateIpAddress.documentation: Describes the private IP address of a network interface.

Association.documentation: The association information for an Elastic IP address associated with the network interface.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether this IP address is the primary private IP address of the network interface.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the instance.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group the instance is in (for cluster compute instances).

Tenancy.documentation: The tenancy of the instance (if the instance is running in a VPC). An instance with a tenancy of dedicated runs on single-tenant hardware.

State.documentation: The state of the placement group.

PriceSchedule.documentation: Describes the price for a Reserved Instance.

Active.documentation:
The current price schedule, as determined by the term remaining for the Reserved Instance in the listing.

A specific price schedule is always in effect, but only one price schedule can be active at any time. Take, for example, a Reserved Instance listing that has five months remaining in its term. When you specify price schedules for five months and two months, this means that schedule 1, covering the first three months of the remaining term, will be active during months 5, 4, and 3. Then schedule 2, covering the last two months of the term, will be active for months 2 and 1.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency for transacting the Reserved Instance resale. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Term.documentation: The number of months remaining in the reservation. For example, 2 is the second to the last month before the capacity reservation expires.

PriceScheduleSpecification.documentation: Describes the price for a Reserved Instance.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency for transacting the Reserved Instance resale. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Term.documentation: The number of months remaining in the reservation. For example, 2 is the second to the last month before the capacity reservation expires.

Count.documentation: The number of instances available for the price.

PrivateIpAddressSpecification.documentation: Describes a secondary private IP address for a network interface.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether the private IP address is the primary private IP address. Only one IP address can be designated as primary.

PropagatingVgw.documentation: Describes a virtual private gateway propagating route.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway (VGW).

InstanceCount.documentation: The number of Reserved Instances to purchase.

LimitPrice.documentation: Specified for Reserved Instance Marketplace offerings to limit the total order and ensure that the Reserved Instances are not purchased at unexpected prices.

ReservedInstancesOfferingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance offering to purchase.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: The IDs of the purchased Reserved Instances.

Architecture.documentation:
The architecture of the AMI.

Default: For Amazon EBS-backed AMIs, i386. For instance store-backed AMIs, the architecture specified in the manifest file.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

ImageLocation.documentation: The full path to your AMI manifest in Amazon S3 storage.

Name.documentation:
A name for your AMI.

Constraints: 3-128 alphanumeric characters, parentheses (()), square brackets ([]), spaces ( ), periods (.), slashes (/), dashes (-), single quotes ('), at-signs (@), or underscores(_)

RootDeviceName.documentation: The name of the root device (for example, /dev/sda1, or /dev/xvda).

SriovNetSupport.documentation:
Set to simple to enable enhanced networking for the AMI and any instances that you launch from the AMI.

There is no way to disable enhanced networking at this time.

This option is supported only for HVM AMIs. Specifying this option with a PV AMI can make instances launched from the AMI unreachable.

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the newly registered AMI.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

AllocationId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The allocation ID. Required for EC2-VPC.

PublicIp.documentation: [EC2-Classic] The Elastic IP address. Required for EC2-Classic.

AssociationId.documentation: The ID of the current association between the original network ACL and the subnet.

NetworkAclId.documentation: The ID of the new network ACL to associate with the subnet.

CidrBlock.documentation: The network range to allow or deny, in CIDR notation.

Egress.documentation:
Indicates whether to replace the egress rule.

Default: If no value is specified, we replace the ingress rule.

IcmpTypeCode.documentation: ICMP protocol: The ICMP type and code. Required if specifying 1 (ICMP) for the protocol.

PortRange.documentation: TCP or UDP protocols: The range of ports the rule applies to. Required if specifying 6 (TCP) or 17 (UDP) for the protocol.

Protocol.documentation: The IP protocol. You can specify all or -1 to mean all protocols.

RuleAction.documentation: Indicates whether to allow or deny the traffic that matches the rule.

RuleNumber.documentation: The rule number of the entry to replace.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR address block used for the destination match. The value you provide must match the CIDR of an existing route in the table.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of an Internet gateway or virtual private gateway.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of a VPC peering connection.

RouteTableId.documentation: The ID of the new route table to associate with the subnet.

Description.documentation: Descriptive text about the health state of your instance.

EndTime.documentation: The time at which the reported instance health state ended.

ReasonCodes.documentation:
One or more reason codes that describes the health state of your instance.

  • instance-stuck-in-state: My instance is stuck in a state.

  • unresponsive: My instance is unresponsive.

  • not-accepting-credentials: My instance is not accepting my credentials.

  • password-not-available: A password is not available for my instance.

  • performance-network: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are network related.

  • performance-instance-store: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are related to the instance stores.

  • performance-ebs-volume: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are related to an EBS volume.

  • performance-other: My instance is experiencing performance problems.

  • other: [explain using the description parameter]

StartTime.documentation: The time at which the reported instance health state began.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation:
The user-specified name for a logical grouping of bids.

When you specify an Availability Zone group in a Spot Instance request, all Spot Instances in the request are launched in the same Availability Zone. Instance proximity is maintained with this parameter, but the choice of Availability Zone is not. The group applies only to bids for Spot Instances of the same instance type. Any additional Spot Instance requests that are specified with the same Availability Zone group name are launched in that same Availability Zone, as long as at least one instance from the group is still active.

If there is no active instance running in the Availability Zone group that you specify for a new Spot Instance request (all instances are terminated, the bid is expired, or the bid falls below current market), then Amazon EC2 launches the instance in any Availability Zone where the constraint can be met. Consequently, the subsequent set of Spot Instances could be placed in a different zone from the original request, even if you specified the same Availability Zone group.

Default: Instances are launched in any available Availability Zone.

InstanceCount.documentation:
The maximum number of Spot Instances to launch.

Default: 1

LaunchGroup.documentation:
The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot Instances that launch together and terminate together.

Default: Instances are launched and terminated individually

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request.

ValidFrom.documentation:
The start date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until all instances launch, the request expires, or the request is canceled. If the request is persistent, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until it expires or is canceled.

Default: The request is effective indefinitely.

ValidUntil.documentation:
The end date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date and time is reached.

Default: The request is effective indefinitely.

RequestSpotLaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for an instance.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instance.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data to make available to the instances.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that owns the reservation.

RequesterId.documentation: The ID of the requester that launched the instances on your behalf (for example, AWS Management Console or Auto Scaling).

ReservedInstanceLimitPrice.documentation: Describes the limit price of a Reserved Instance offering.

Amount.documentation: Used for Reserved Instance Marketplace offerings. Specifies the limit price on the total order (instanceCount * price).

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency in which the limitPrice amount is specified. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the Reserved Instance can be used.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency of the Reserved Instance. It's specified using ISO 4217 standard currency codes. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Duration.documentation: The duration of the Reserved Instance, in seconds.

End.documentation: The time when the Reserved Instance expires.

FixedPrice.documentation: The purchase price of the Reserved Instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type on which the Reserved Instance can be used.

RecurringCharges.documentation: The recurring charge tag assigned to the resource.

Start.documentation: The date and time the Reserved Instance started.

State.documentation: The state of the Reserved Instance purchase.

UsagePrice.documentation: The usage price of the Reserved Instance, per hour.

ReservedInstancesConfiguration.documentation: Describes the configuration settings for the modified Reserved Instances.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the modified Reserved Instances.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type for the modified Reserved Instances.

Platform.documentation: The network platform of the modified Reserved Instances, which is either EC2-Classic or EC2-VPC.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: Describes the ID of a Reserved Instance.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive key supplied by the client to ensure that the request is idempotent. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

InstanceCounts.documentation: The number of instances in this state.

PriceSchedules.documentation: The price of the Reserved Instance listing.

ReservedInstancesListingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance listing.

Status.documentation: The status of the Reserved Instance listing.

StatusMessage.documentation: The reason for the current status of the Reserved Instance listing. The response can be blank.

UpdateDate.documentation: The last modified timestamp of the listing.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive key supplied by the client to ensure that the request is idempotent. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

CreateDate.documentation: The time when the modification request was created.

EffectiveDate.documentation: The time for the modification to become effective.

ModificationResults.documentation: Contains target configurations along with their corresponding new Reserved Instance IDs.

ReservedInstancesIds.documentation: The IDs of one or more Reserved Instances.

ReservedInstancesModificationId.documentation: A unique ID for the Reserved Instance modification.

Status.documentation: The status of the Reserved Instances modification request.

UpdateDate.documentation: The time when the modification request was last updated.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: The ID for the Reserved Instances that were created as part of the modification request. This field is only available when the modification is fulfilled.

TargetConfiguration.documentation: The target Reserved Instances configurations supplied as part of the modification request.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the Reserved Instance can be used.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency of the Reserved Instance offering you are purchasing. It's specified using ISO 4217 standard currency codes. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Duration.documentation: The duration of the Reserved Instance, in seconds.

FixedPrice.documentation: The purchase price of the Reserved Instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type on which the Reserved Instance can be used.

Marketplace.documentation: Indicates whether the offering is available through the Reserved Instance Marketplace (resale) or AWS. If it's a Reserved Instance Marketplace offering, this is true.

PricingDetails.documentation: The pricing details of the Reserved Instance offering.

RecurringCharges.documentation: The recurring charge tag assigned to the resource.

ReservedInstancesOfferingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance offering.

UsagePrice.documentation: The usage price of the Reserved Instance, per hour.

Attribute.documentation: The attribute to reset (currently you can only reset the launch permission attribute).

SourceDestCheck.documentation: The source/destination checking attribute. Resets the value to true.

Attribute.documentation: The attribute to reset (currently only the attribute for permission to create volumes can be reset).

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types.

IpPermissions.documentation: A set of IP permissions. You can't specify a destination security group and a CIDR IP address range.

IpProtocol.documentation: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers). Use -1 to specify all.

SourceSecurityGroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the destination security group. You can't specify a destination security group and a CIDR IP address range.

SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the destination security group. You can't specify a destination security group and a CIDR IP address range.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type.

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types.

GroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the security group.

IpPermissions.documentation: A set of IP permissions. You can't specify a source security group and a CIDR IP address range.

IpProtocol.documentation: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers). Use -1 to specify all.

SourceSecurityGroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the source security group. You can't specify a source security group and a CIDR IP address range.

SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId.documentation: The ID of the source security group. You can't specify a source security group and a CIDR IP address range.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type.

Route.documentation: Describes a route in a route table.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block used for the destination match.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of a gateway attached to your VPC.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

InstanceOwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the instance.

Origin.documentation:
Describes how the route was created.

  • CreateRouteTable indicates that route was automatically created when the route table was created.
  • CreateRoute indicates that the route was manually added to the route table.
  • EnableVgwRoutePropagation indicates that the route was propagated by route propagation.

State.documentation: The state of the route. The blackhole state indicates that the route's target isn't available (for example, the specified gateway isn't attached to the VPC, or the specified NAT instance has been terminated).

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

Associations.documentation: The associations between the route table and one or more subnets.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the route table.

RouteTableAssociation.documentation: Describes an association between a route table and a subnet.

Main.documentation: Indicates whether this is the main route table.

RouteTableAssociationId.documentation: The ID of the association between a route table and a subnet.

Enabled.documentation: Indicates whether monitoring is enabled for the instance.

ClientToken.documentation:
Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

Constraints: Maximum 64 ASCII characters

DisableApiTermination.documentation:
If you set this parameter to true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. If you set this parameter to true and then later want to be able to terminate the instance, you must first change the value of the disableApiTermination attribute to false using ModifyInstanceAttribute. Alternatively, if you set InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior to terminate, you can terminate the instance by running the shutdown command from the instance.

Default: false

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal Amazon EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

Default: false

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the AMI, which you can get by calling DescribeImages.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation:
Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

Default: stop

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type. For more information, see Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

Default: m1.small

KernelId.documentation:
The ID of the kernel.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

KeyName.documentation:
The name of the key pair. You can create a key pair using CreateKeyPair or ImportKeyPair.

If you launch an instance without specifying a key pair, you can't connect to the instance.

MaxCount.documentation:
The maximum number of instances to launch. If you specify more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches the largest possible number of instances above MinCount.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 General FAQ.

MinCount.documentation:
The minimum number of instances to launch. If you specify a minimum that is more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches no instances.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 General FAQ.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The primary IP address. You must specify a value from the IP address range of the subnet.

Only one private IP address can be designated as primary. Therefore, you can't specify this parameter if PrivateIpAddresses.n.Primary is set to true and PrivateIpAddresses.n.PrivateIpAddress is set to an IP address.

Default: We select an IP address from the IP address range of the subnet.

RamdiskId.documentation:
The ID of the RAM disk.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation:
One or more security group IDs. You can create a security group using CreateSecurityGroup.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

SecurityGroups.documentation:
[EC2-Classic, default VPC] One or more security group names. For a nondefault VPC, you must use security group IDs instead.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

SubnetId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the subnet to launch the instance into.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data for the instances.

S3Storage.documentation: Describes the storage parameters for S3 and S3 buckets for an instance store-backed AMI.

AWSAccessKeyId.documentation: The access key ID of the owner of the bucket. Before you specify a value for your access key ID, review and follow the guidance in Best Practices for Managing AWS Access Keys.

Bucket.documentation: The bucket in which to store the AMI. You can specify a bucket that you already own or a new bucket that Amazon EC2 creates on your behalf. If you specify a bucket that belongs to someone else, Amazon EC2 returns an error.

Prefix.documentation: The beginning of the file name of the AMI.

UploadPolicy.documentation: A Base64-encoded Amazon S3 upload policy that gives Amazon EC2 permission to upload items into Amazon S3 on your behalf.

UploadPolicySignature.documentation: The signature of the Base64 encoded JSON document.

IpPermissions.documentation: One or more inbound rules associated with the security group.

IpPermissionsEgress.documentation: [EC2-VPC] One or more outbound rules associated with the security group.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the security group.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the security group.

VpcId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the VPC for the security group.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The full ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (KMS) master key that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the parent volume.

OwnerAlias.documentation: The AWS account alias (for example, amazon, self) or AWS account ID that owns the snapshot.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the Amazon EBS snapshot owner.

Progress.documentation: The progress of the snapshot, as a percentage.

StartTime.documentation: The time stamp when the snapshot was initiated.

State.documentation: The snapshot state.

VolumeSize.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

SnapshotDetail.documentation: The details of the snapshot created from the imported disk.

DeviceName.documentation: The Amazon EBS block device mapping for the snapshot.

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of progress for the task.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Status.documentation: A brief status of the snapshot creation.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the snapshot creation.

Url.documentation: The URL used to access the disk image.

SnapshotDiskContainer.documentation: The disk container object for the ImportSnapshot request.

Description.documentation: The description of the disk image being imported.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image being imported.

Url.documentation: The URL to the Amazon S3-based disk image being imported. It can either be a https URL (https://..) or an Amazon S3 URL (s3://..).

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of completion for the ImportSnapshot task.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Status.documentation: A brief status for the ImportSnapshot task.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the ImportSnapshot task.

Url.documentation: The URL of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

SpotDatafeedSubscription.documentation: Describes the data feed for a Spot Instance.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket where the Spot Instance data feed is located.

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot Instance request, if any.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the account.

Prefix.documentation: The prefix that is prepended to data feed files.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot Instance data feed subscription.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation: The Availability Zone group. If you specify the same Availability Zone group for all Spot Instance requests, all Spot Instances are launched in the same Availability Zone.

CreateTime.documentation: The time stamp when the Spot Instance request was created.

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot Instance request, if any.

InstanceId.documentation: The instance ID, if an instance has been launched to fulfill the Spot Instance request.

LaunchGroup.documentation: The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot Instances that launch together and terminate together.

LaunchedAvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the bid is launched.

ProductDescription.documentation: The product description associated with the Spot Instance.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot Instance request.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot Instance request. Spot bid status information can help you track your Spot Instance requests. For more information, see Spot Bid Status in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

Status.documentation: The status code and status message describing the Spot Instance request.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until all instances launch, the request expires, or the request is canceled. If the request is persistent, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until it expires or is canceled.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date is reached.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the Spot Instance state change.

Message.documentation: The message for the Spot Instance state change.

SpotInstanceStatus.documentation: Describes the status of a Spot Instance request.

UpdateTime.documentation: The time of the most recent status update.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group (for cluster instances).

SpotPrice.documentation: Describes the maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price (bid) that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance.

Timestamp.documentation: The date and time the request was created.

StartingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more started instances.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the state change.

Message.documentation:
The message for the state change.

  • Server.SpotInstanceTermination: A Spot Instance was terminated due to an increase in the market price.

  • Server.InternalError: An internal error occurred during instance launch, resulting in termination.

  • Server.InsufficientInstanceCapacity: There was insufficient instance capacity to satisfy the launch request.

  • Client.InternalError: A client error caused the instance to terminate on launch.

  • Client.InstanceInitiatedShutdown: The instance was shut down using the shutdown -h command from the instance.

  • Client.UserInitiatedShutdown: The instance was shut down using the Amazon EC2 API.

  • Client.VolumeLimitExceeded: The volume limit was exceeded.

  • Client.InvalidSnapshot.NotFound: The specified snapshot was not found.

Force.documentation:
Forces the instances to stop. The instances do not have an opportunity to flush file system caches or file system metadata. If you use this option, you must perform file system check and repair procedures. This option is not recommended for Windows instances.

Default: false

StoppingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more stopped instances.

Storage.documentation: Describes the storage location for an instance store-backed AMI.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the subnet.

AvailableIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of unused IP addresses in the subnet. Note that the IP addresses for any stopped instances are considered unavailable.

CidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block assigned to the subnet.

DefaultForAz.documentation: Indicates whether this is the default subnet for the Availability Zone.

MapPublicIpOnLaunch.documentation: Indicates whether instances launched in this subnet receive a public IP address.

State.documentation: The current state of the subnet.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC the subnet is in.

Key.documentation:
The key of the tag.

Constraints: Tag keys are case-sensitive and accept a maximum of 127 Unicode characters. May not begin with aws:

Value.documentation:
The value of the tag.

Constraints: Tag values are case-sensitive and accept a maximum of 255 Unicode characters.

ResourceId.documentation: The ID of the resource. For example, ami-1a2b3c4d.

TerminatingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more terminated instances.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: The secondary private IP addresses to unassign from the network interface. You can specify this option multiple times to unassign more than one IP address.

InstanceMonitorings.documentation: Monitoring information for one or more instances.

UserBucket.documentation: User's Amazon S3 bucket details used to access the image.

S3Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket name where the disk image is located.

S3Key.documentation: The Amazon S3 Key for the disk image.

UserBucketDetails.documentation: User's Amazon S3 bucket details used to access the image.

S3Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket from which the disk image was created.

S3Key.documentation: The Amazon S3 key from which the disk image was created.

UserIdGroupPair.documentation: Describes a security group and AWS account ID pair.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the security group. In a request, use this parameter for a security group in EC2-Classic or a default VPC only. For a security group in a nondefault VPC, use GroupId.

UserId.documentation: The ID of an AWS account. EC2-Classic only.

LastStatusChange.documentation: The date and time of the last change in status.

OutsideIpAddress.documentation: The Internet-routable IP address of the virtual private gateway's outside interface.

StatusMessage.documentation: If an error occurs, a description of the error.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the volume.

CreateTime.documentation: The time stamp when volume creation was initiated.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the volume will be encrypted.

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For General Purpose (SSD) volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information on General Purpose (SSD) baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide for Linux.

Constraint: Range is 100 to 20000 for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes and 3 to 10000 for General Purpose (SSD) volumes.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1 volumes; it is not used in requests to create standard or gp2 volumes.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The full ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (KMS) master key that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the volume.

Size.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiBs.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot from which the volume was created, if applicable.

State.documentation: The volume state.

VolumeType.documentation: The volume type. This can be gp2 for General Purpose (SSD) volumes, io1 for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes, or standard for Magnetic volumes.

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the Amazon EBS volume is deleted on instance termination.

State.documentation: The attachment state of the volume.

Size.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

Code.documentation: The code identifying the operation, for example, enable-volume-io.

EventId.documentation: The ID of the event associated with this operation.

EventType.documentation: The event type associated with this operation.

Status.documentation: The intended status of the volume status.

NotAfter.documentation: The latest end time of the event.

NotBefore.documentation: The earliest start time of the event.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the volume.

Events.documentation: A list of events associated with the volume.

DhcpOptionsId.documentation: The ID of the set of DHCP options you've associated with the VPC (or default if the default options are associated with the VPC).

InstanceTenancy.documentation: The allowed tenancy of instances launched into the VPC.

IsDefault.documentation: Indicates whether the VPC is the default VPC.

State.documentation: The current state of the VPC.

VpcAttachment.documentation: Describes an attachment between a virtual private gateway and a VPC.

State.documentation: The current state of the attachment.

VpcClassicLink.documentation: Describes whether a VPC is enabled for ClassicLink.

ClassicLinkEnabled.documentation: Indicates whether the VPC is enabled for ClassicLink.

ExpirationTime.documentation: The time that an unaccepted VPC peering connection will expire.

Status.documentation: The status of the VPC peering connection.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

VpcPeeringConnectionStateReason.documentation: Describes the status of a VPC peering connection.

Code.documentation: The status of the VPC peering connection.

Message.documentation: A message that provides more information about the status, if applicable.

VpcPeeringConnectionVpcInfo.documentation: Describes a VPC in a VPC peering connection.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the VPC owner.

CustomerGatewayConfiguration.documentation: The configuration information for the VPN connection's customer gateway (in the native XML format). This element is always present in the CreateVpnConnection response; however, it's present in the DescribeVpnConnections response only if the VPN connection is in the pending or available state.

CustomerGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the customer gateway at your end of the VPN connection.

Routes.documentation: The static routes associated with the VPN connection.

State.documentation: The current state of the VPN connection.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the VPN connection.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway at the AWS side of the VPN connection.

StaticRoutesOnly.documentation: Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.
Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone where the virtual private gateway was created.

State.documentation: The current state of the virtual private gateway.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the virtual private gateway.

Type.documentation: The type of VPN connection the virtual private gateway supports.

VpcAttachments.documentation: Any VPCs attached to the virtual private gateway.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

VpnStaticRoute.documentation: Describes a static route for a VPN connection.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block associated with the local subnet of the customer data center.

State.documentation: The current state of the static route.
